trans-unit.source: Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based Virtual Machines
trans-unit.target: Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based Virtual Machines

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based virtual machines in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Windows-based virtual machines in Azure.

trans-unit.source: These steps show you how to customize a set of Azure PowerShell commands that create and preconfigure a Windows-based Azure virtual machine by using a building block approach.
trans-unit.target: These steps show you how to customize a set of Azure PowerShell commands that create and preconfigure a Windows-based Azure virtual machine by using a building block approach.

trans-unit.source: You can use this process to quickly create a command set for a new Windows-based virtual machine and expand an existing deployment or to create multiple command sets that quickly build out a custom dev/test or IT pro environment.
trans-unit.target: You can use this process to quickly create a command set for a new Windows-based virtual machine and expand an existing deployment or to create multiple command sets that quickly build out a custom dev/test or IT pro environment.

trans-unit.source: These steps follow a fill-in-the-blanks approach for creating Azure PowerShell command sets.
trans-unit.target: These steps follow a fill-in-the-blanks approach for creating Azure PowerShell command sets.

trans-unit.source: This approach can be useful if you are new to PowerShell or you just want to know what values to specify for successful configuration.
trans-unit.target: This approach can be useful if you are new to PowerShell or you just want to know what values to specify for successful configuration.

trans-unit.source: Advanced PowerShell users can take the commands and substitute their own values for the variables (the lines beginning with "$").
trans-unit.target: Advanced PowerShell users can take the commands and substitute their own values for the variables (the lines beginning with "$").

trans-unit.source: For the companion topic to configure Linux-based virtual machines, see <linkText>Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Linux-based Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the companion topic to configure Linux-based virtual machines, see <linkText>Use Azure PowerShell to create and preconfigure Linux-based Virtual Machines</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create and preconfigure a Windows Virtual Machine with Resource Manager and Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: If you haven't done so already, use the instructions in <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't done so already, use the instructions in <linkText>How to install and configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> to install Azure PowerShell on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: Then, open an Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: Then, open an Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: Set your Azure subscription and storage account by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt. Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.
trans-unit.target: Set your Azure subscription and storage account by running these commands at the Azure PowerShell command prompt. Replace everything within the quotes, including the < and > characters, with the correct names.

trans-unit.source: You can get the correct subscription name from the SubscriptionName property of the output of the Get-AzureSubscription command.
trans-unit.target: You can get the correct subscription name from the SubscriptionName property of the output of the Get-AzureSubscription command.

trans-unit.source: You can get the correct storage account name from the Label property of the output of the Get-AzureStorageAccount command after you run the Select-AzureSubscription command.
trans-unit.target: You can get the correct storage account name from the Label property of the output of the Get-AzureStorageAccount command after you run the Select-AzureSubscription command.

trans-unit.source: Next, you need to determine the ImageFamily or Label value for the specific image corresponding to the Azure virtual machine you want to create.
trans-unit.target: Next, you need to determine the ImageFamily or Label value for the specific image corresponding to the Azure virtual machine you want to create.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples from the Gallery in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples from the Gallery in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You can get the list of available ImageFamily values with this command.
trans-unit.target: You can get the list of available ImageFamily values with this command.

trans-unit.source: Here are some examples of ImageFamily values for Windows-based computers:
trans-unit.target: Here are some examples of ImageFamily values for Windows-based computers:

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1

trans-unit.source: Windows Server Technical Preview
trans-unit.target: Windows Server Technical Preview

trans-unit.source: SQL Server 2012 SP1 Enterprise on Windows Server 2012
trans-unit.target: SQL Server 2012 SP1 Enterprise on Windows Server 2012

trans-unit.source: If you find the image you are looking for, open a fresh instance of the text editor of your choice or the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).
trans-unit.target: If you find the image you are looking for, open a fresh instance of the text editor of your choice or the PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).

trans-unit.source: Copy the following into the new text file or the PowerShell ISE, substituting the ImageFamily value.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following into the new text file or the PowerShell ISE, substituting the ImageFamily value.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, the image name is in the Label property instead of the ImageFamily value.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, the image name is in the Label property instead of the ImageFamily value.

trans-unit.source: If you didn't find the image that you are looking for using the ImageFamily property, list the images by their Label property with this command.
trans-unit.target: If you didn't find the image that you are looking for using the ImageFamily property, list the images by their Label property with this command.

trans-unit.source: If you find the right image with this command, open a fresh instance of the text editor of your choice or the PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: If you find the right image with this command, open a fresh instance of the text editor of your choice or the PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Copy the following into the new text file or the PowerShell ISE, substituting the Label value.
trans-unit.target: Copy the following into the new text file or the PowerShell ISE, substituting the Label value.

trans-unit.source: Build the rest of your command set by copying the appropriate set of blocks below into your new text file or the ISE and then filling in the variable values and removing the < and > characters. See the two <linkText>examples</linkText><title></title> at the end of this article for an idea of the final result.
trans-unit.target: Build the rest of your command set by copying the appropriate set of blocks below into your new text file or the ISE and then filling in the variable values and removing the < and > characters. See the two <linkText>examples</linkText><title></title> at the end of this article for an idea of the final result.

trans-unit.source: Start your command set by choosing one of these two command blocks (required).
trans-unit.target: Start your command set by choosing one of these two command blocks (required).

trans-unit.source: Option 1: Specify a virtual machine name and a size.
trans-unit.target: Option 1: Specify a virtual machine name and a size.

trans-unit.source: Option 2: Specify a name, size, and availability set name.
trans-unit.target: Option 2: Specify a name, size, and availability set name.

trans-unit.source: For the InstanceSize values for D-, DS-, or G-series virtual machines, see <linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For the InstanceSize values for D-, DS-, or G-series virtual machines, see <linkText>Virtual Machine and Cloud Service Sizes for Azure</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, for a standalone Windows computer, specify the local administrator account and password.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, for a standalone Windows computer, specify the local administrator account and password.

trans-unit.source: Choose a strong password.
trans-unit.target: Choose a strong password.

trans-unit.source: To check its strength, see <linkText>Password Checker: Using Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To check its strength, see <linkText>Password Checker: Using Strong Passwords</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, to add the Windows computer to an existing Active Directory domain, specify the local administrator account and password, the domain, and the name and password of a domain account.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, to add the Windows computer to an existing Active Directory domain, specify the local administrator account and password, the domain, and the name and password of a domain account.

trans-unit.source: For additional pre-configuration options for Windows-based virtual machines, see the syntax for the Windows and WindowsDomain parameter sets in Add-AzureProvisioningConfig.
trans-unit.target: For additional pre-configuration options for Windows-based virtual machines, see the syntax for the Windows and WindowsDomain parameter sets in Add-AzureProvisioningConfig.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, assign the virtual machine a specific IP address, known as a static DIP.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, assign the virtual machine a specific IP address, known as a static DIP.

trans-unit.source: You can verify that a specific IP address is available with:
trans-unit.target: You can verify that a specific IP address is available with:

trans-unit.source: Optionally, assign the virtual machine to a specific subnet in an Azure virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, assign the virtual machine to a specific subnet in an Azure virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, add a single data disk to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, add a single data disk to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: For an Active Directory domain controller, set $hcaching to "None".
trans-unit.target: For an Active Directory domain controller, set $hcaching to "None".

trans-unit.source: Optionally, add the virtual machine to an existing load-balanced set for external traffic.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, add the virtual machine to an existing load-balanced set for external traffic.

trans-unit.source: Finally, choose one of these required command blocks for creating the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Finally, choose one of these required command blocks for creating the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Option 1: Create the virtual machine in an existing cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Option 1: Create the virtual machine in an existing cloud service.

trans-unit.source: The short name of the cloud service is the name that appears in the list of Cloud Services in the Azure Management Portal or in the list of Resource Groups in the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: The short name of the cloud service is the name that appears in the list of Cloud Services in the Azure Management Portal or in the list of Resource Groups in the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: Option 2: Create the virtual machine in an existing cloud service and virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Option 2: Create the virtual machine in an existing cloud service and virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Review the Azure PowerShell command set you built in your text editor or the PowerShell ISE consisting of multiple blocks of commands from step 4. Ensure that you have specified all the needed variables and that they have the correct values. Also make sure that you have removed all the < and > characters.
trans-unit.target: Review the Azure PowerShell command set you built in your text editor or the PowerShell ISE consisting of multiple blocks of commands from step 4. Ensure that you have specified all the needed variables and that they have the correct values. Also make sure that you have removed all the < and > characters.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a text editor, copy the command set to the clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell command prompt.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a text editor, copy the command set to the clipboard and then right-click your open Azure PowerShell command prompt.

trans-unit.source: This will issue the command set as a series of PowerShell commands and create your Azure virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This will issue the command set as a series of PowerShell commands and create your Azure virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Alternately, run the command set in the PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Alternately, run the command set in the PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: If you will be creating this virtual machine again or a similar one, you can:
trans-unit.target: If you will be creating this virtual machine again or a similar one, you can:

trans-unit.source: Save this command set as a PowerShell script file (*.ps1).
trans-unit.target: Save this command set as a PowerShell script file (*.ps1).

trans-unit.source: Save this command set as an Azure automation runbook in the Automation section of the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Save this command set as an Azure automation runbook in the Automation section of the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Here are two examples of using the steps above to build Azure PowerShell command sets that create Windows-based Azure virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Here are two examples of using the steps above to build Azure PowerShell command sets that create Windows-based Azure virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: I need a PowerShell command set to create the initial virtual machine for an Active Directory domain controller that:
trans-unit.target: I need a PowerShell command set to create the initial virtual machine for an Active Directory domain controller that:

trans-unit.source: Uses the Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter image.
trans-unit.target: Uses the Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter image.

trans-unit.source: Has the name AZDC1.
trans-unit.target: Has the name AZDC1.

trans-unit.source: Is a standalone computer.
trans-unit.target: Is a standalone computer.

trans-unit.source: Has an additional data disk of 20 GB.
trans-unit.target: Has an additional data disk of 20 GB.

trans-unit.source: Has the static IP address 192.168.244.4.
trans-unit.target: Has the static IP address 192.168.244.4.

trans-unit.source: Is in the BackEnd subnet of the AZDatacenter virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Is in the BackEnd subnet of the AZDatacenter virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Is in the Azure-TailspinToys cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Is in the Azure-TailspinToys cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Here is the corresponding Azure PowerShell command set to create this virtual machine, with blank lines between each block for readability.
trans-unit.target: Here is the corresponding Azure PowerShell command set to create this virtual machine, with blank lines between each block for readability.

trans-unit.source: I need a PowerShell command set to create a virtual machine for a line-of-business server that:
trans-unit.target: I need a PowerShell command set to create a virtual machine for a line-of-business server that:

trans-unit.source: Uses the Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter image.
trans-unit.target: Uses the Windows Server 2012 R2 Datacenter image.

trans-unit.source: Has the name LOB1.
trans-unit.target: Has the name LOB1.

trans-unit.source: Is a member of the corp.contoso.com domain.
trans-unit.target: Is a member of the corp.contoso.com domain.

trans-unit.source: Has an additional data disk of 200 GB.
trans-unit.target: Has an additional data disk of 200 GB.

trans-unit.source: Is in the FrontEnd subnet of the AZDatacenter virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Is in the FrontEnd subnet of the AZDatacenter virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Is in the Azure-TailspinToys cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Is in the Azure-TailspinToys cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Here is the corresponding Azure PowerShell command set to create this virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Here is the corresponding Azure PowerShell command set to create this virtual machine.
